The body mass index (BMI) or Quetelet index is a value derived from the mass (weight) and height of an individual. The BMI is defined as the body mass divided by the square of the body height, and is universally expressed in units of kg/m2, resulting from mass in kilograms and height in metres.
Underweight: \nA BMI of under %2$s indicates that you are underweight, so you may need to put on some weight. You are recommended to ask your doctor or a dietitian for advice.
Normal: \nA BMI of %1$s-%2$s indicates that you are at a healthy weight for your height. By maintaining a healthy weight, you lower your risk of developing serious health problems.

Overweight: \nA BMI of %1$s-%2$s indicates that you are slightly overweight. You may be advised to lose some weight for health reasons. You are recommended to talk to your doctor or a dietitian for advice.
Obese: \nA BMI of %1$s-%2$s indicates that you are heavily overweight. Your health may be at risk if you do not lose weight. You are recommended to talk to your doctor or a dietitian for advice.
Extremely Obese: \nA BMI of over %1$s indicates that you are morbidly overweight. Your health is certainly at risk if you do not lose weight. You are recommended to talk to your doctor immediately.
